Description.val:
Submarine Life Support System procures Low Pressure Electrolyzer (LPE) oxygen generators to fulfill the Program of Record requirement to replace the legacy obsolete high pressure Electrolytic Oxygen Generator (EOG) on SSBNs.  The LPE is critical to the OHIO Class to achieve service life extension to 42 years. Procurements are tied to specific submarine availabilities since a major ship alteration is required for installation.

[P40A / SUBMARINE LIFE SUPPORT SYSTEM]: 5D830 - PRODUCTION ENGINEERING The review and approval of any production contract technical documentation, or the separate development of this documentation to include, technical manuals, Preventive Maintenance Schedule, Level III production drawings, Provisioning Technical Documentation, Program Support Data and Allowance Parts Lists; Engineering & support for final design reviews.  This work can be accomplished by NSWC PHILA as the in-service engineering agent, other Naval activities or contractors as appropriate.

[P3A - 2 / LOW PRESSURE ELECTROLYZER]: 5D010 - THE LOW PRESSURE ELECTROLYZER (LPE) The LPE will replace the EOG currently being used on SSBN/SSGN Class submarines. The LPE produces oxygen at low pressure, eliminating the need for high pressure oxygen storage. There will be two LPEs on each SSBN/SSGN Class submarine. EOG's must be replaced by LPE's on OHIO SSBNs to ensure they can sustain current operational availability requirements through their 42 yr service life. Oxygen Generators are necessary to maintain submarine stealth while on mission. Therefore, procurements are driven by the OHIO Class maintenance period schedule. The replacement of the EOG with the LPE must be done during a major maintenance availability due to the time to complete the installation. As OHIO Class submarine approach the end of service life there are fewer major maintenance periods remaining, increasing the number of concurrent procurements required. Current install schedule supports achieving OHIO Class service life extension to 42 years. Differences in unit costs above inflation are due to the number of units being procured each fiscal year. Unit costs are impacted by quantities of scale.

Justification.val:
The FY 2019 funding request was reduced by $0.015 million to reflect the Department of Navy's effort to support the Office of Management and Budget directed reforms for Efficiency and Effectiveness that include a lean, accountable, more efficient government.

FY19 Budget request procures 4 LPE units and installs 3 procurements from prior years.

Name.@footnote: Funding changed to reflect level of effort needed for new contract awarded and anticipating upcoming work.

Due to FY15 contract solicitation receiving no interested bidders, FY15 funding was obligated in FY16 when a LPE procurement contract was awarded.  The FY15 First Article Unit (FAU) contract was awarded 13 JUL 16 with delivery scheduled for 2018.  FY16 and FY17 installation funding was moved to procurement to allow for purchase of units needed to complete program.  Only 1 LPE will be delivered in FY18 for installation due to FAU testing requirements for new contract qualification.  Upon completion of qualification testing, unit will be refurbished and installed on a submarine.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Method:: Installation Name: Installation Group Name
